rememberedPersonSummary.name: Linda Lowthian
story:
Linda has been fighting breast cancer for almost 11 years since her first diagnosis. She faced a mastectomy and intense chemo which almost killed her twice, but she fought through and got the all clear news every family hopes for. Her health began deteriorating around 3 years ago and symptoms were missed signalling that her cancer had returned and spread. The confirmation that the cancer had come back happened in May 2020 and that it had spread to her brain, spine, tonsil, ribs and hip which was untreatable devastating us all.

Treatment began to suppress her symptoms and make life more comfortable for her, but shortly after starting, her beloved husband Keith passed away in September, knocking Linda back significantly. As a family we navigated the next 2 months as best we could, grieving and fighting the cancer during the covid19 pandemic adding its own challenges. 

On Thursday the 26th of November, she tested positive for Covid19 and on Friday the 27th she was admitted to the Cumberland Infirmary. She fought hard and showed real improvement against the covid pneumonia. However on Sunday the 6th of December 2 hours after a wonderfully positive FaceTime with her daughter Kerry, she suffered from a tension pneumothorax on her lung, a rare but devastating complication. Linda deteriorated very quickly, however her dad Tom also in the same hospital ward fighting covid pneumonia was able to be by her side and hold her hand until she peacefully passed. 

Although the cancer was a secondary cause of death, her battle was hard prior to the covid illness and your donation can support others going through such a difficult battle, hopefully contributing to beating this disease once and for all. 

On behalf of Linda’s family, thank you.

Diving for Donations!
Two of our directors, James Fry and Marc Whittingham have volunteered/been roped into taking part in a skydive for charity.

Our Salisbury office is located next to Old Sarum airfield, where people frequently take to the sky to jump out of planes from great heights. Having watched hundreds of jumpers over the years we have been here, we decided it's about time that some of the team take part.

Marc is jumping for Macmillan Cancer Support whilst James is jumping for Salisbury Hospice,  both of which are remarkable charities that we are extremely proud to be supporting. We are hoping to raise a combined total of £1,500, so £750 for each charity. 

We have separate Just Giving pages for each jumper/charity. You can find James' page for Salisbury Hospice here: https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/jamesdirectorsdive

We will be sharing videos and photos of the skydive once it has been completed so you can enjoy watching James and Marc's expressions as they freefall from 10,000 feet.

Any donations are greatly appreciated!


Many thanks,

Blue Frontier

I have chosen Macmillan because of the support and hard work they have shown my amazingly strong cousin during her battle with lymphoma. She is an inspiration to so many showing courage and strength and this is my way to help support her!

To minimise contact you as the parents will provide the gift for me to hand to the children, and leave it outside hidden for me to pick up on arrival for them. (I will be wearing gloves (Santa ones!) so no contamination will be made).

story:
As you know I have had a Guide Dog Pup in lockdown and he's been an absolute delight. He has made us laugh a lot probably the funniest dog we've ever had. He has provided us with some challenges we have overcome and as any dog owner knows given focus in challenging times. 

Instead of the My Guide service I usually do,  I have been calling visually impaired people on their own and continue to do so. I have met some really interesting people, heard about some of the challenges they have been facing in this environment. Believe me it's not easy. I have completed over 110 hours of telephone calls this year so far. 

Did you know it costs £56,000 to provide and support a guide dog through it working life. Guide Dogs support over 5,000 dogs in the UK. They have their own national breeding programme, now up and running again thank goodness and their staff have worked really hard to get the dogs through training for people on the waiting list. Its also not all about the dogs there are many other services they provide to support people and visually impaired children. 

So importantly - Any small donation will be gratefully received and there will be a voucher of your choice for the winners of £25.00, so get swotting. 

Roy, Anne & Murphy have already donated prior to me setting this page up so folks they are not bah humbug and our sincere thanks. 

We have enjoyed meeting all the new friends the happy campers and some of our old friends in this awful year.

We hope you all have a good, be it different,  Christmas and a Happy New year to you all. Lets hope next summer we can all meet up again !!! 

Take care everyone - Love - Anne & David, Pierre x Guide Dog Pup , Dann our in training Guide Dog Pup. xxx

story:
At the end of April 2019 we'd raised £2,500 towards Nationwide's Name A Puppy Appeal and were exactly on track for the £5,000 needed by April 2021 to name a puppy for Nationwide! 

But then coronavirus came along and prevented us from having our hugely popular 'Pat and chat' events, where our colleagues come along during their lunch hour and for a small donation, get to meet the wonderful Guide Dogs and their owners to hear in person how these amazing creatures make such a difference of those with sight loss.

So like so many other events, we've been unable to host the Guide Dogs at our admin centres and raise money towards our appeal...until now! With Christmas approaching, why not give the gift of a donation for family or friends or instead of sending Christmas cards?

So many charities have been hit so hard this year, so any donation you can afford to give is so much appreciated to help our appeal and those who depend on a Guide Dog to go about their daily life. For people with sight loss, social isolation can be their every day. 

We appreciate times are difficult right now, but every pound we raise will ensure we can continue to help people with sight loss and feel less alone, now and in the future. It costs £13 a day to support each of our life changing dogs.

Thank you : )

story:
Mary Bolland from Larkhall will reach the incredible age of
100 on 22 December, and to celebrate this momentous birthday we have set up
this page where all donations will go directly to the Guide Dogs charity.

Mary, who has been totally blind since the age of 9 has had
Guide Dogs since 1962 who have enabled her to have an  incredibly active and independent life.

She travelled from Larkhall to Bolton to train with her
first Guide Dog in 1962 FLASH, as there were no facilities then in Scotland.

Mary then trained with her other Guide Dogs in Scotland in
both the Forfar and Larkhall Centres, namely:

ENID

ANNABEL

WANDA

HANNAH

VIDA

Most people from Larkhall and the surrounding communities
will fondly remember this very friendly lady out and about with her dogs over
the years, Mary loved nothing more than a good catch up when out and about and
thoroughly enjoyed her weekly visits to William McKenzies salon.

Her Guide Dogs meant so much to Mary and likewise every
penny donated to the charity will equally mean a lot to her.

Our aim is to raise £5k, this would allow us to sponsor and
dedicate a Guide Dog to Mary, naming it in her honour.

Mary is now enjoying life in a care home in East Kilbride,
having enjoyed so many years with her Guide Dogs and will be amazed and very
humbled with any donations that can kindly be given to celebrate this iconic
birthday.

As well as Mary receiving a telegram from Her Majesty The
Queen, she could also have a Guide Dog pup named in her honour, a pup that will
go on to give a blind person the fabulous life that Mary has enjoyed!

We would like to thank everyone for any donations that you
can kindly offer to celebrate the magnificent 100 years of Mary Bolland, a
Larkhall Legend

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

On Friday 18th December we shall be taking part in Festive Friday to support GOSH. We are asking for a small contribution from our families and in return our young people are able to wear Christmas fancy dress on this day.

Whether you rock as reindeers, sparkle as snowflakes, shine as Santas or simply love fabulously festive attire, join the fancy dress fun at OAB this December with Great Ormond Street Hospital Children Charity’s Festive Fridays!

Whatever festive theme you choose for your fancy dress, you’ll be raising money to help fund the vital resources Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) needs to help get more seriously ill children home to their families.

The difference you'll make Every child should have the chance to be at home with their families at Christmas. That’s why the dedicated teams at GOSH work around the clock to find the cures and treatments to ensure seriously ill children have the best chance of getting home to their families. And, for those children whose treatment needs to continue over the festive season, they try to make the hospital feel like a home from home.

In these extraordinary times the hospital and the children it cares for need your support more than ever. As GOSH continues to feel the impact of the pandemic over the coming months its needs will continue to change and increase.

Never has there been a greater chance for OAB to make an incredible difference. The NHS covers the day-to-day running costs of the hospital but your support is needed to help GOSH go above and beyond, providing extraordinary care and expertise to children with the rarest and most complex conditions, who come to GOSH from across the UK.

story:
In loving memory of Sam Shippey, a devoted husband, dad, brother, grandad and great grandad who had an amazing zest for life 

Married to Diana for 62 years, had 2 children, 6 grandchildren and 1 great grandson

He worked for a local specialised Magnet company in Essex for 65 years

He was 87 years young, super talented artist and photographer. His binoculars, camera and telescope traveled everywhere with him to see and capture that perfect still

His love was birds and wildlife as a whole and was an active volunteer down at the RSPB Reserve at Rainham Marshes making many a close friend. His knowledge was second to none and he loved nothing more than to share his passion with others. He  was a true gentleman, inspirational, kind and funny, an all round "smashing bloke" that will be sorely missed and never replaced 

Sam was known as "Mr Rainham Marshes"

His other passion in life was aviation. His favourite aircraft was his beloved Spitfire, one that he would have dearly loved to have been able to fly in. He hot air ballooned, glided and also flew in a Tiger Moth just some of his adventures

Sam broke the mould, one in a million, a true legend.........RIP

This memory, this laughter got me through my first ever 5k in May, and my 10k in September and it will hopefully get me through all 13.1 miles of this too! 

Many of you know I lost my mum and that laughter on June 22nd 2017. Some of you may not know about the 3 weeks before that which my mum spent in a hospice. We could not have been more grateful for that place. My mum hated the hospital and refused to go back which is how she ended up surrounded by the caring, loving, truly amazing staff who became her friends at the very worst point of her life. At the end I spent a full 72 hours in that place, and they couldn’t have done more for me. These people are truly the best of the human race. 

So I’m putting myself through hell to raise money for the people who held my hand the last time I went through it, and I hope you’ll help me.
